G.L. c. 218, \u00a719.proposition: This Court has subject‑matter jurisdiction under G.L. c. 218, §19, as this action arises under Massachusetts law and the amount in controversy does not exceed the jurisdictional limit of the District Court.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a714.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, §14, a landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises shall be liable for damages of not less than one month’s rent or actual damages, whichever is greater, and reasonable attorney’s fees and costs.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment ensures that a tenant shall not be disturbed in her possession and beneficial use of leased premises.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.support_reasoning: The opinion is primarily about constructive eviction and landlord responsibility for third-party noise, not a direct definition of the covenant. However, the court repeatedly frames the issue as deprivation of "quiet enjoyment" and "beneficial enjoyment" of the demised premises, treating the covenant as protecting the tenant’s ability to occupy and beneficially use the premises. While not a textbook definitional statement, the reasoning is consistent with and supports the claimed proposition.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.relevant_excerpt: "There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done... (landlord authorizing another lessee to obstruct the tenant’s light and air, necessary for the beneficial enjoyment of the demised premises)."

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment ensures that a tenant shall not be disturbed in her possession and beneficial use of leased premises.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly explains the meaning of “quiet enjoyment” in landlord-tenant law as the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with the tenancy that impair the character and value of the premises. That description aligns with the proposition that the covenant protects the tenant’s possession and beneficial use of the leased premises, and the court ties § 14’s statutory protection to this common-law covenant.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) (quoting from Brande v. Grace, 154 Mass. 210, 212 [1891]). … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy.”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: A landlord’s substantial failure to provide essential services such as heat or hot water constitutes a breach of the covenant.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion directly holds that the landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season “constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment,” treating heat as an essential service whose substantial non-provision breaches the covenant. Although the case specifically concerns quiet enjoyment and heat, the reasoning is clearly applicable to essential services and matches the proposition that such a substantial failure is a covenant breach.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season … seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. … [L]iability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.proposition: A landlord’s substantial failure to provide essential services such as heat or hot water constitutes a breach of the covenant.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.support_reasoning: The case concerns whether a violation of the lead paint statute, without more, constitutes a violation of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment; it does not address essential services like heat or hot water. The court discusses that negligent failure to repair known defects can violate the covenant but gives only examples (including other cases) and does not itself hold that substantial failure to provide heat or hot water is a breach. Thus, this opinion does not directly establish the specific proposition cited.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850 (.relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: A prolonged lack of hot water has been held to materially interfere with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the landlord’s obligation to provide heat and hot water and holds that an oral agreement shifting that obligation to the tenant is ineffective without a written letting agreement. However, the decision does not address a factual situation involving a prolonged lack of hot water, nor does it analyze whether such a condition constitutes a material interference with quiet enjoyment. It is therefore not authority for the specific proposition that a prolonged lack of hot water materially interferes with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt: “The State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. §§ 410.190 and 410.201 (1983), provides that the owner of a dwelling ‘shall’ supply heat and hot water ‘except and to the extent that the occupant is required to supply the fuel under a written letting agreement.’ … The plain and unambiguous language of the regulation indicates that a writing is required when the obligation to provide heat and hot water is transferred to the tenant.”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: A prolonged lack of hot water has been held to materially interfere with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly holds that loss of heat and hot water can be a material breach of the implied warranty of habitability, entitling the tenant to rent abatement. It does not, however, analyze or decide the issue in terms of a covenant of quiet enjoyment or "material interference with quiet enjoyment"; the case is framed entirely as a warranty-of-habitability/rent abatement issue. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific quiet-enjoyment proposition stated.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: "He found and ruled that the losses of heat and hot water were material breaches of the warranty of habitability. The judge ruled further that the tenant is allowed to abate the rent from the date the landlord had notice of the breach of the warranty of habitability."

Arsenault v. Chicopee Hous. Auth., 15 Ma.raw_text: Arsenault v. Chicopee Hous. Auth., 15 Mass. App. Ct. 939 (1983)
Arsenault v. Chicopee Hous. Auth., 15 Ma.proposition: The landlord’s good intentions or efforts to repair do not excuse the deprivation where the result is a serious interference with habitability.
Arsenault v. Chicopee Hous. Auth., 15 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns eligibility of a remaining household member in public housing and the requirement to use the housing authority’s grievance procedure before eviction. It does not discuss habitability, conditions of the premises, serious interference with habitability, or whether a landlord’s good-faith efforts to repair excuse such interference. Therefore it does not provide authority for the stated proposition about habitability and landlord intent.
Arsenault v. Chicopee Hous. Auth., 15 Ma.relevant_excerpt: We do not choose at this time between the competing interpretations or express any final opinion about the views of the judge, which on the surface appear artificial and impractical. At least in the present situation — where no reading by the agency of the critical regulation has been brought forward — we think the judge should have acted on the wrongful refusal of the Authority to process the grievance and remitted the parties to the grievance procedure…

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: Deficiencies in essential services like hot water also breach the implied warranty of habitability, further evidencing a violation of the quiet enjoyment covenant.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: This concurring/dissenting opinion discusses the implied warranty of habitability and ties it to compliance with the State Sanitary Code, but it does not specifically address deficiencies in essential services like hot water as a distinct example, nor does it link such deficiencies to a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The judge instead argues for an implied obligation to meet statutory minimum standards, with rent abatement as a remedy, and expressly distances his approach from the broader, undefined ‘warranty of habitability’ concept adopted by the majority. Thus, it does not clearly support the specific proposition stated.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.”}

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).proposition: Deficiencies in essential services like hot water also breach the implied warranty of habitability, further evidencing a violation of the quiet enjoyment covenant.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).support_reasoning: The opinion clearly finds a breach of the implied warranty of habitability based on serious conditions (no heat, structural defects, infestation), but it does not specifically discuss lack of hot water or “essential services like hot water” as part of that analysis. Nor does it link any deficiency in such services to a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment; the quiet enjoyment/c.186 §14 claim is mentioned only in the background and not analyzed as to elements. Thus, the case does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).relevant_excerpt: “After his view, the judge made express findings. Among other defects, the judge found that: (1) there was no functioning heating system; (2) several basement windows were missing; (3) the apartment windows were in deplorable condition and without screens; (4) ceiling fixtures were missing; (5) the walls and ceilings were cracked and had holes; (6) doors were missing knobs; (7) the flooring in places was hazardous; and (8) the apartment was infested with cockroaches and rodents…. On the G.L.c. 93A counterclaim, the judge found that Gonzalez had suffered two discrete injuries…[including] diminution in value of the apartment due to Haddad's breach of the warranty of habitability.”

105 C.M.R. \u00a7410.190(A).proposition: Massachusetts sanitary code regulations require landlords to provide hot and cold running water in every dwelling.

McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.raw_text: McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304, 308 (1977)
McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.proposition: The violation of such code provisions supports a finding of breach of quiet enjoyment.
McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.support_reasoning: This opinion deals with breach of the implied warranty of habitability and the proper measure of damages, not breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Although it repeatedly treats State Sanitary Code violations as the basis for a breach of the implied warranty and for rent abatement, it does not analyze or hold that such violations support a finding of breach of quiet enjoyment. Using this case to support a proposition about quiet enjoyment misstates its scope.
McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.relevant_excerpt:
“This case returns to us following its remand to the Superior Court for computation by the trial judge of the damages owed to a tenant by his landlord for breach of the implied warranty of habitability. Under that warranty principle… the judge had awarded damages to the plaintiff McKenna… for violations of the State Sanitary Code….

…[T]here may be instances in which minor violations in conjunction with major violations or a multitude of minor violations with a cumulative effect on habitability should be taken into consideration in reducing rent.”
